## Set up your session

1b. Check your working directory.

1c. Read in all four raw data files associated with the EPA Air dataset, being sure to set string columns to be read in a factors. See the README file for the EPA air datasets for more information (especially if you have not worked with air quality data previously).

## Wrangle individual datasets to create processed files.

3. Change date columns to be date objects.

4. Select the following columns: Date, DAILY_AQI_VALUE, Site.Name, AQS_PARAMETER_DESC, COUNTY, SITE_LATITUDE, SITE_LONGITUDE

5. For the PM2.5 datasets, fill all cells in AQS_PARAMETER_DESC with "PM2.5" (all cells in this column should be identical).

6. Save all four processed datasets in the Processed folder. Use the same file names as the raw files but replace "raw" with "processed".

```{r wrangle individual datasets}
#3 Change date columns to date objects
EPA.O3.18$Date <- mdy(EPA.O3.18$Date)
EPA.O3.19$Date <- mdy(EPA.O3.19$Date)
EPA.PM25.18$Date <- mdy(EPA.PM25.18$Date)
EPA.PM25.19$Date <- mdy(EPA.PM25.19$Date)

#4 Select columns
EPA.O3.18.sub <- select(EPA.O3.18, Date, DAILY_AQI_VALUE, Site.Name, AQS_PARAMETER_DESC, COUNTY, SITE_LATITUDE, SITE_LONGITUDE)
EPA.O3.19.sub <- select(EPA.O3.19, Date, DAILY_AQI_VALUE, Site.Name, AQS_PARAMETER_DESC, COUNTY, SITE_LATITUDE, SITE_LONGITUDE)
EPA.PM25.18.sub <- select(EPA.PM25.18, Date, DAILY_AQI_VALUE, Site.Name, AQS_PARAMETER_DESC, COUNTY, SITE_LATITUDE, SITE_LONGITUDE)
EPA.PM25.19.sub <- select(EPA.PM25.19, Date, DAILY_AQI_VALUE, Site.Name, AQS_PARAMETER_DESC, COUNTY, SITE_LATITUDE, SITE_LONGITUDE)

#5 Mutate column values
EPA.PM25.18.sub <- mutate(EPA.PM25.18.sub, AQS_PARAMETER_DESC = 'PM2.5')
EPA.PM25.19.sub <- mutate(EPA.PM25.19.sub, AQS_PARAMETER_DESC = 'PM2.5')

#6 Save processed datasets
write.csv(EPA.O3.18.sub, row.names = FALSE, file = "./Data/Processed/EPAair_O3_NC2018_Processed.csv")
write.csv(EPA.O3.19.sub, row.names = FALSE, file = "./Data/Processed/EPAair_O3_NC2019_Processed.csv")
write.csv(EPA.PM25.18.sub, row.names = FALSE, file = "./Data/Processed/EPAair_PM25_NC2018_Processed.csv")
write.csv(EPA.PM25.19.sub, row.names = FALSE, file = "./Data/Processed/EPAair_PM25_NC2019_Processed.csv")
```


## Combine datasets

7. Combine the four datasets with `rbind`. Make sure your column names are identical prior to running this code.

8. Wrangle your new dataset with a pipe function (%>%) so that it fills the following conditions: 

  * Include all sites that the four data frames have in common: "Linville Falls", "Durham Armory", "Leggett", "Hattie Avenue", "Clemmons Middle", "Mendenhall School", "Frying Pan Mountain", "West Johnston Co.", "Garinger High School", "Castle Hayne", "Pitt Agri. Center", "Bryson City", "Millbrook School" (the function `intersect` can figure out common factor levels - but it will include sites with missing site information...) 

  * Some sites have multiple measurements per day. Use the split-apply-combine strategy to generate daily means: group by date, site name, AQS parameter, and county. Take the mean of the AQI value, latitude, and longitude.
  
  * Add columns for "Month" and "Year" by parsing your "Date" column (hint: `lubridate` package)
  
  * Hint: the dimensions of this dataset should be 14,752 x 9.

9. Spread your datasets such that AQI values for ozone and PM2.5 are in separate columns. Each location on a specific date should now occupy only one row.

10. Call up the dimensions of your new tidy dataset.

11. Save your processed dataset with the following file name: "EPAair_O3_PM25_NC1819_Processed.csv"

```{r wrangle combined dataset, message = FALSE}
#7 Combine data sets
EPAair <- rbind(EPA.O3.18.sub, EPA.O3.19.sub, EPA.PM25.18.sub, EPA.PM25.19.sub)

#8 Wrangle data set using pipe
EPAair.processed <- 
  EPAair %>%
  filter(Site.Name %in% c("Linville Falls", "Durham Armory", "Leggett", "Hattie Avenue", "Clemmons Middle", "Mendenhall School", "Frying Pan Mountain", "West Johnston Co.", "Garinger High School", "Castle Hayne", "Pitt Agri. Center", "Bryson City", "Millbrook School")) %>%
  group_by(Date, Site.Name, AQS_PARAMETER_DESC, COUNTY) %>%
  summarise(meanAQI = mean(DAILY_AQI_VALUE),
            meanlatitude = mean(SITE_LATITUDE),
            meanlongitude = mean(SITE_LONGITUDE)) %>%
  mutate(Year = year(Date)) %>%
  mutate(Month = month(Date)) 

#9 Spread the dataset
EPAair.spread <- 
  pivot_wider(EPAair.processed, names_from = AQS_PARAMETER_DESC, values_from = meanAQI)

#10 Call up dimensions
dim(EPAair.spread)

#11 Save dataset
write.csv(EPAair.spread, row.names = FALSE, file = "./Data/Processed/EPAair_O3_PM25_NC1819_Processed.csv")
```


## Generate summary tables

12. Use the split-apply-combine strategy to generate a summary data frame. Data should be grouped by site, month, and year. Generate the mean AQI values for ozone and PM2.5 for each group. Then, add a pipe to remove instances where mean **ozone** values are not available (use the function `drop_na` in your pipe). It's ok to have missing mean PM2.5 values in this result. 

13. Call up the dimensions of the summary dataset.

```{r split-apply-combine, message=FALSE}
#12 Summarize data
EPAair.summaries <- 
  EPAair.spread %>%
  group_by(Site.Name, Month, Year) %>%
  drop_na(Ozone) %>%
  summarise(meanOzone = mean(Ozone), 
            meanPM2.5 = mean(PM2.5))

#13 Call up dimensions
dim(EPAair.summaries)
```

14. Why did we use the function `drop_na` rather than `na.omit`?

> Answer: The function drop_na can be applied to columns in a dataframe while na.omit can only be applied to the dataset level.
